content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A nonconducting sphere of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> is centered on the origin. The sphere has a negative uniform volume charge density <math alttext="rho sub sphere equals negative rho sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>sphere</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The sphere is surrounded by a nonconducting spherical shell of inner radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and outer radius <math alttext="2 R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>. The shell has a positive uniform volume charge density <math alttext="rho sub shell equals positive rho sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>shell</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure. Points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are located on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis at positions <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 2 R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 3 R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, respectively.

The magnitude of the electric fields at points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are <math alttext="E sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub C" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <msub> <mi>E</mi> <mtext>C</mtext> </msub> </mstyle> </math> respectively.
content.question: (a) Rank the values <math alttext="E sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> from greatest to least. Without using equations, justify your answer using physics principles.

frqParts.text: (a) Rank the values <math alttext="E sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> from greatest to least. Without using equations, justify your answer using physics principles.

(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

Consider a new case where instead of having a uniform volume charge density, the charge density of the sphere varies with the radius of the sphere as given by <math alttext="rho sub sphere, of lowercase r, equals, the fraction with numerator negative rho sub 0, and denominator R, end fraction, times lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>sphere</mtext></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mi>R</mi></mfrac><mi>r</mi></mstyle></math>. In this case, the electric field at Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is <math alttext="E sub B comma new, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B,new</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>.
(c) Will the value of <math alttext="E sub B comma new, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B,new</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> be greater than, less than, or equal to the value of <math alttext="E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, which was derived in part (b)? Justify your claim with relevant physics principles.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
